awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Does a Range Shifting Species Alter Ecosystem Function?
awd_abstract_narration:
Organisms that feed on plants play important roles in moving energy and nutrients though ecosystems, which underlies many services that ecosystems provide to societies such as fisheries, clean drinking water, and carbon storage. However, the identity and abundance of organisms in ecosystems is changing as warm-climate species move into previously cooler regions that are disproportionately impacted by climate change. Understanding how these species movements alter ecosystem processes is an important step in anticipating and managing the impacts of climate change on ecosystems and their services.  This research investigates how the establishment and subsequent population boom of a novel aquatic insect species into high elevation wetlands influences the timing and magnitude of processes central to all ecosystems, namely the consumption of plant material, the cycling of nutrients that support plant and animal growth, the availability of prey for predators, and the connections between freshwater habitats and the surrounding terrestrial environment. In addition to scientific advancement, this research advances early childhood education via childrens’ science camps, provides opportunities for public outreach during science tours at a field station, and trains the next generation of scientists by engaging undergraduate students from historically underrepresented groups in field-based ecological research.


This research tests the novel hypothesis that the dominance of a range-shifting species with life history characteristics that differ from resident species will shift the phenology and magnitude of ecosystem processes, altering food-web energy transfer, and resulting in ecosystem state-shifts. Specifically, this research investigates the ecosystem impact of a large increase in the abundance of a recent range-shifting caddisfly (Nemotaulius hostilis) with novel life history trait of larval development occurring in the fall and winter, rather than summer like resident species. The research combines field measurements of organism biomass with assays of nutrient cycling and detritus processing to 1) quantify range-shifting and resident caddisfly population size and energy transfer to salamander predator populations; 2) experimentally test density-dependent competition for detritus resources between range-shifting and resident caddisflies; 3) leverage established models and a 30-year dataset on caddisfly and salamander abundance to estimate the past, contemporary, and future ecosystem-process-outcomes associated with range-shifting and resident caddisflies including detritus decomposition, nutrient release, and subsidies to the terrestrial ecosystem. This combined approach investigating interlinked ecosystem compartments generates a strong mechanistic understanding with general application. Moreover, by integrating the keystone top-predator into the research, we will develop new understanding of how top-down control influences the ecosystem outcomes of range shifts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The function of natural ecosystems depends on the interactive roles of the various species that coexist in nature. However, species distributions around the planet are shifting in response to a changing climate, altering the identity and abundance of organisms in an ecosystem that perform important ecosystem functions. Our research in mountain wetlands focusses on the ecosystem impacts of a species of aquatic insect (a caddisfly) that has recently moved upslope from wetlands on the valley floors to ponds at tree line. While most of the caddisflies in our system hatch from eggs in spring, grow as aquatic larvae in summer, and emerge as flying adults in late summer, this new species hatches in fall, overwinters as larvae (when other caddisflies are absent from ponds) and emerges as a flying adult in spring. Our research shows that this novel seasonal life cycle (1) provides a new food source for aquatic salamanders to build body condition before the winter, (2) alters the seasonal timing of aquatic biomass in ponds, and (3) the emergence of caddisfly adults provide a new, early spring subsidy of aquatic food to land predators like birds and bats. However, not all ecosystem processes have been altered by this new caddisfly: while these caddisflies are important to the consumption of dead plant material, we observed little change in the rate and seasonal timing of this important ecosystem process. Similarly, the new caddisfly does not appear to compete strongly with resident species and may even fertilize algae and microbes by excreting high levels of nutrients. Overall, our research indicates that the movement of new species into high elevation ecosystems has the potential to alter the timing of important ecosystem processes and generate new food-web connections among resident species. These processes are central to almost all ecosystem types, so our results provide clues to the future of ecosystems that are being rearranged by shifts in species distributions. Moreover, high elevation wetlands harbor unique biodiversity and are important components of water systems in the western USA. Therefore, understanding how species rearrangements influence ecosystem processes such as carbon and nutrient dynamics provides information on the potential for changes in water quality and other aquatic ecosystem services. 

 

Our research has supported the career development of numerous scientists, including the promotion and tenure of an assistant professor to associate professor with tenure, and an associate professor to full professor, and has contributed to the training of two postdocs, three PhD students, one MS student and eight undergraduate students conducting independent research. Our research has been communicated in seven peer-reviewed scientific papers (five published or in-press, two in review), as well as numerous conference presentations, public talks, public outreach and engagement. Our research has been incorporated into undergraduate and graduate coursework at four different universities and one biological field station. We have also used our research to develop field-based learning activities that, in the past two years, has engaged >2,000 grade 3-12 students from 28 different schools in New England.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/27/2024
Modified by: Hamish Greig
